docs.lead_paragraph: At first, whenever Janice Wallace closed her eyes, she could still see her big sister, Lori Moran, laughing and blowing kisses through the window of the taxi speeding toward Kennedy International Airport. For hours, she clung to that memory of Ms. Moran, a 34-year-old figure-skating coach who had planned to toast her third wedding anniversary in the French Alps. But yesterday, as Mrs. Wallace watched television news flashes of rescue workers pulling baby bottles, ripped clothing and seat cushions from the choppy sea off Peggy's Cove, Nova Scotia, she turned her attention to the business of bringing her sister's body back home.

headline.main: Families' Last, Grim Task Is Just to Identify the Bodies
headline.kicker: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 111: THE VICTIMS

docs.abstract: Grieving relatives of 299 people killed in Swissair crash fly to Nova Scotia on Swissair charter flights; photo of search personnel; daughter of John Mortimer, retired New York Times executive who died, reports authorities warn bodies canot be identified; victims also include 34-year-old skating coach Lori Moran, cancer researcher Eugenia Spanopoulou, 49-year-old son of boxer Jake LaMotta, and medical researcher Roger R Williams, bound for WHO meeting in Geneva; some others noted (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Health insurers cannot deny benefits for injuries caused by domestic violence under a bill signed into law yesterday by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

headline.main: Health Benefits Assured In Domestic Violence

docs.abstract: Gov Christine Whitman signs New Jersey legislation prohibiting health insurers from denying coverage for injuries caused by domestic violence (S)
docs.snippet: Health insurers cannot deny benefits for injuries caused by domestic violence under a bill signed into law yesterday by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

docs.lead_paragraph: For the last three decades, two groups that should be obvious bedfellows -- the labor movement and leftist intellectuals -- have far more often acted as enemies than as allies. Close partners throughout the first half of this century, these two had an ugly breakup in the 1960's over Vietnam, integration and the vehemence of cold war anti-Communism.

headline.main: Labor and the Left: Getting Cozy Again; But Common Goals May Not Be Enough to Revive a Potent Alliance

docs.abstract: Labor movement and leftist intellectuals, close partners in first half of century, are attempting reconciliation after three decades of estrangement over Vietnam, integration and cold war anti-Communism; Steven Fraser and other prime movers admit they want to end left's exile from power; pro-labor group first banded together in 1996, encouraged by new AFL-CIO president John J Sweeney; prominent members noted; photos; neoconservatives like Norman Podhoretz, who were labor's friends decade ago, not surprisingly ridicule intellectual leftists as desperate midgets eager to piggyback on labor giant so they can be seen and heard again (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Angry at the school board on the second day of the teachers' strike here, Joan Muso kept her two daughters home today. She said that no security checks had been completed on substitutes hired for $225 a day. ''I feel the conditions are very unsafe,'' she said. ''I'll teach my kids at home.''

headline.main: Enmity From School Strike Spreads to Town

docs.abstract: Parents in Middletown, New Jersey, are angry at teachers' strike; tension is underlined by teacher's' complaints that board of education is poisoning atmosphere by depicting them as rude, anti-student and boisterous; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania's largest health insurer has agreed to pay a $38.5 million fine to settle accusations that it had manipulated Medicare claims reports given to Federal auditors. The agreement between the Government and the insurer, Highmark Inc., came after a two-year investigation, David Barasch, the United States Attorney, said on Thursday.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Health Insurer Agrees To Pay $38 Million Fine

docs.abstract: Highmark Inc, which was formed by consolidation of Pennsylvania Blue Shield and Blue Cross of Western Pennsylvania, agrees to pay $38.5 million fine to settle accusations that Pennsylvania Blue Shield manipulated Medicare claims reports given to Federal auditors (S)
docs.snippet: Pennsylvania's largest health insurer has agreed to pay a $38.5 million fine to settle accusations that it had manipulated Medicare claims reports given to Federal auditors.    The agreement between the Government and the insurer, Highmark Inc., came...

docs.lead_paragraph: Allied Specialty Services, a claims-processing company for four of New Jersey's largest health maintenance organizations, has been dropped by one of these managed care insurers, and its contract with another is being reviewed. Allied, which is based in Florida, lost its account with H.M.O. Blue, the state's second largest H.M.O., which announced the decision in a letter last Monday. The contract was canceled two days before doctors and some health consumer groups publicly accused Allied of delaying, denying and decreasing claims payments to specialists in a way that threatened the solvency of some medical practices and distorting the decisions of health care providers. Allied has denied that such problems exist.

headline.main: Claims Processor Loses Contract With Blue Cross

docs.abstract: Allied Specialty Services, claims-processing company for four New Jersey HMOs, loses account with HMO Blue; doctors and consumer groups are accusing Florida-based Allied of improper delays and claim denials; NYLCare Health Plans reviews its contract; third-party administrators like Allied have emerged in last 15 years with growth of managed care (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a speech that her aides billed as a major policy address, Geraldine A. Ferraro said last night that government should help relieve some of the financial burden borne by families of the chronically ill, and she called for a comprehensive Federal regulation of the long-term-care industry. Her opponents in the Democratic primary race for United States Senate -- Mark Green and Charles E. Schumer -- also avowed their commitment to protecting the vulnerable.

headline.main: Senate Candidates Stress Aid for the Young, Old and Ill

docs.abstract: Geraldine A Ferraro, Democratic candidate for US Senate, in speech in New York City to Democratic Leadership for 21st Century, says that government should help relieve some of financial burden borne by families of chronically ill, and calls for Federal regulation of long-term-care industry; her opponents, New York City Public Advocate Mark Green and Rep Charles E Schumer, also avow their commitment to protecting vulnerable; Green, speaking in Rochester, says he wants to create social security system for children; Schumer, speaking to elderly residents of Prospect Park Residence in Brooklyn, emphasizes his record of defending Medicare and Social Security (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Just three and a half hours before the first day of school yesterday, teachers went on strike in the largest district in Monmouth County, N.J. The walkout in Middletown Township came as predawn bargaining failed after two years of futile negotiations and frosty relations between the sprawling suburb's 800 teachers and its school board. The strike guaranteed a rocky start to the new school year for 10,000 students.

headline.main: A District's School Year Begins With a Strike

docs.abstract: Middletown Township, NJ, teachers go on strike just three and half hours before first day of school; walkout comes as predawn bargaining fails after two years of futile negotiations and frosty relations between sprawling suburb's 800 teachers and its school board (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of doctors and consumer advocates said today that the company that processes claims of more than half the state's 2.3 million health maintenance organization subscribers has endangered the solvency of doctors and hospitals by denying claims and delaying payments. They also said that through a loophole in state law, these companies that do nothing but process claims are not themselves considered insurers and therefore are out of the reach of state regulators.

headline.main: Denials and Delays on H.M.O. Claims Said to Hurt Doctors

docs.abstract: Group of doctors and consumer advocates says that Allied Specialty Services, company that processes claims of more than half of state's 2.3 million health maintenance organization subscribers has endangered solvency of doctors and hospitals by denying claims and delaying payments; also say that under loophole in state law, companies such as Allied do nothing but process claims and are not themselves considered insurers and therefore are out of reach of state regulators (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An advisory committee of the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously yesterday to recommend approval of the drug tamoxifen to reduce women's risk of developing breast cancer. Although the drug, which is already on the market, is intended only for women at high risk of breast cancer, and the advisory panel was cautious in its wording, tamoxifen's approval would be a milestone in efforts to prevent cancer.

headline.main: Drugs to Fight Breast Cancer Near Approval

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration advisory committee votes unanimously to recommend approval of drug tamoxifen to reduce women's risk of developing breast cancer; tamoxifen's approval would be milestone in efforts to prevent cancer; drug, which is already on market, is intended only for women at high risk of breast cancer; advisory panel unanimously recommends approval for new drug, Herceptin, for women with advanced breast cancer; officials say drug is intended for use by estimated 30 percent of breast cancer patients who have too many copies of gene called HER2/neu, making cancer aggressively spread through body (M)
